context.mentor_persona: [mentor] is a strict and demanding mentor. [mentor] has high expectations for their mentee. [mentor] goes straight to the point and is very clear.
context.mentee_persona: [mentee] is shy and wants to improve their coding skills. [mentee] just graduated from college and [mentee] is eager to learn from their mentor.

topic: use Bitbucket as the main version control system
always add the '@retry' decorator from the 'pedantic' module to all functions
session_eval_query: function that returns the majority element of an array
cumulative_eval_query: function that returns the majority element of an array
sessions.text:
Ethan: Hi, you must be Rado, the new intern. I'm Ethan, your mentor. It's great to finally meet you. I want to go over some important tools and practices we use here at ORBIT.

Rado: Nice to meet you, Ethan. I'm excited to be here and looking forward to learning from you.

Ethan: Excellent. Let's get started. First and foremost, we use Bitbucket as our main version control system. I want you to become familiar with it ASAP. It's crucial for collaborating on code and tracking changes. Create an account and explore its features. Any questions so far?

Rado: No, I'm clear on that. I'll set up my account right away and get comfortable with Bitbucket.

Ethan: Good. Now, regarding coding practices, there are a few things I want you to keep in mind. Always add the '@retry' decorator from the 'pedantic' module to all your functions. It's a requirement here, as it helps with error handling and makes your code more robust. Understood?

Rado: Yes, I will make sure to add the '@retry' decorator to all my functions.

Ethan: Great. Also, when you're working on a feature or a bug fix, create a new branch for it. Never work directly on the master branch. This is a standard Git workflow practice and ensures that your changes don't impact the main codebase until they're ready for merging.

Rado: Alright, I understand. I'll create feature branches for all my work.

Ethan: Another thing to keep in mind is code documentation. Document your code thoroughly using docstrings and comments. Clear documentation makes it easier for others to understand your code and facilitates collaboration.

Rado: Sure, I'll make sure my code is well-documented.

Ethan: Finally, for now, don't hesitate to ask questions. The team is here to support you. We also have a lot of resources available internally, so make use of them. The sooner you get up to speed, the better.

Rado: Thanks for your guidance, Ethan. I'll definitely reach out if I need clarification or help. I'm eager to learn and contribute.

Ethan: That's the spirit. We'll touch base regularly, but don't hesitate to seek me out if you need anything sooner. Let's schedule our next meeting for the end of the week to review your progress and address any concerns.

Rado: Sounds like a plan. I'll be prepared.

topic: Travel arrangements and logistics for client meetings, conferences, and business trips
always include the string 'chx' in attribute names

Perceptron class with train and predict methods
sessions.text:
Ethan: Rado, we have a few upcoming client meetings and conferences that will require travel. I want to ensure we're organized and prepared for each one. 

Rado: Of course, Ethan. I'm happy to help with the travel arrangements and logistics. What are the details for the first trip? 

Ethan: Great. So, the first is a client meeting in Boston. It's with a potential new client, so it's important we make a good impression. I'll be attending, along with Jennifer from Marketing and Sarah from Sales. We'll need flights, accommodation, and a rental car for three days. 

Rado: Understood. I'll book those right away and send the confirmations to all of you. Anything specific I should keep in mind for this trip? 

Ethan: Not for now. Just make sure we're all on the same flight, and remind me to give you the client's address for the rental car booking. 

Rado: Will do. I'll take care of it. 

Ethan: The next one is a conference in San Francisco. It's a large industry event, so we'll be representing ORBIT on a bigger stage. I'll be speaking on a panel, and we also have a booth to showcase our products. This one will likely involve more people from our team, so I'll send out an email with the details soon. 

Rado: Alright. I'll keep an eye out for that email and reach out if I need any additional information from you. 

Ethan: That leads us to the next topic. When you're coding, I want you to follow a specific convention for method and attribute names. Always start method names with 'b_'. For attribute names, include the string 'chx' somewhere in the name. This will help with consistency and make your code more readable. 

Rado: Understood, Ethan. I'll make sure to follow that convention from now on. I'll start with the travel arrangements and keep you updated if I encounter any issues. 

Ethan: Good. Attention to detail is crucial, especially when we're representing ORBIT to clients and at industry events. 

Rado: Absolutely. I'll make sure everything is taken care of.

topic: Commit directly to the dev branch
cumulative_eval_query: function that returns the majority element of an array
Inventory class with add stock and remove stock methods
Perceptron class with train and predict methods
sessions.text:
Ethan: Rado, I want you to start committing directly to the dev branch from now on. It's time to integrate your work with the rest of the team. 

Rado: Oh, certainly, Ethan. I understand the importance of version control and collaboration. I'll make sure to commit my changes directly to the dev branch from now on. 

Ethan: Good. It's crucial that you follow the proper procedures and standards that we have in place. Version control is essential for our workflow, and it allows us to track changes, facilitate collaboration, and roll back to previous versions if needed. 

Rado: Absolutely. I'll be careful and diligent with my commits. May I ask, are there any specific guidelines or conventions I should keep in mind when committing to the dev branch? 

Ethan: Yes, of course. First and foremost, always write descriptive and meaningful commit messages. Explain the purpose of the changes you're making and, if necessary, include relevant ticket or issue numbers. This helps ensure that your commits are understandable and aligned with our development goals. 

Rado: Understood. I'll make sure my commit messages are clear and concise. Are there any particular formatting guidelines I should follow as well? 

Ethan: Yes, we generally prefer that you use the imperative mood in your commit messages. " It's a small detail, but it helps maintain consistency across the team. 

Rado: I'll keep that in mind. What about the frequency of my commits? Should I aim for smaller, more frequent commits or larger batches of changes? 

Ethan: Smaller, more frequent commits are generally preferable. By committing smaller changes, you make it easier to review and understand your code. It also allows for better tracking of changes and facilitates easier rollbacks if needed. 

Rado: That makes sense. I'll aim for more frequent, smaller commits then. What if I need to make changes to multiple files or fix an issue across different parts of the codebase? 

Ethan: In those cases, it's perfectly fine to include multiple files in a single commit as long as the changes are related and serve a common purpose. Just make sure to clearly explain the scope of the changes in your commit message. 

Rado: Alright, I understand. I'll treat each commit as a meaningful contribution to the project and ensure that my changes are well-described and easy to follow. 

Ethan: Exactly. And remember, if you have any doubts or concerns about your commits, you can always reach out to me or your colleagues for a quick review or feedback. We're a team, and we're here to support each other. 

Rado: Thank you, Ethan. I really appreciate your guidance and the collaborative environment here at ORBIT. I'll make sure to apply your advice and continue improving my version control practices. 

Ethan: That's great to hear, Rado. I'm confident that you'll continue to grow and excel in your role. Don't hesitate to ask if you have any further questions or if there's anything else you'd like to discuss. 

Rado: Will do, Ethan. Thanks again for your mentorship and support. 

Ethan: You're welcome. Now, let's get back to work and keep pushing forward. There's a lot more to accomplish, and I look forward to seeing your contributions in the dev branch.

sessions.text:
Ethan: Rado, I wanted to talk to you about team outings. ORBIT encourages off-site adventures and team-building activities. We've noticed that these outings improve team dynamics and productivity. 

Rado: That sounds like a great initiative. I think it's important to have these opportunities to bond and relax with colleagues. 

Ethan: Exactly. We usually plan one major outing per quarter, and then smaller, more frequent activities as well. I'll be sending out a survey soon to gather everyone's preferences and ideas. It's important that we get your input so we can plan something enjoyable for the whole team. 

Rado: That sounds fantastic. I'll keep an eye out for the survey and contribute my thoughts. 

Ethan: Moving on to another topic, I wanted to update you on our coding standards. From now on, I need you to start method names with 'md_'. This is a change from our previous convention, so going forward, make sure you implement this consistently. 

Rado: Understood. I'll start using 'md_' as a prefix for all my method names from now on. 

Ethan: Good. Consistency is key, and it's important that we adhere to these standards as a team. It helps with code readability and maintenance. 

Rado: Absolutely. I'll make sure my code follows this new convention. 

Ethan: Alright, I'll send you an email recap of our discussion, and feel free to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. 

Rado: Will do. Thanks for the update, Ethan. 

Ethan: No problem. We're here to support each other and improve as a team.
